title: 107_hr5413
content: The "Dividend Incentive and Tax Simplification Act of 2002" allows for a deduction for dividends paid by corporations under section 250 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Dividend Incentive and Tax Simplification Act of 2002" allows domestic corporations to deduct dividends paid during the taxable year, with exceptions for certain types of dividends. No other deductions are allowed for these dividends. The "Dividend Incentive and Tax Simplification Act of 2002" allows domestic corporations to deduct dividends paid during the taxable year, with exceptions for certain types of dividends. No other deductions are allowed for these dividends. Additionally, a clerical amendment was made to the table of sections for part VIII of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Code. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002. Dividends received by individuals taxed at capital gain rates. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include dividends taxed as net capital gain, defined as net capital gain increased by qualified dividend income from domestic corporations. The distribution of dividends includes various types of income exempt from tax, such as dividends from real estate investment trusts, deductions for dividends paid by mutual savings banks, dividends described in section 404(k), and dividends on stock not meeting holding period requirements. The requirements of section 246(c) are not met for nonresident aliens, only applying in certain cases for determining tax on dividends connected to US business activities. Treatment of dividends from regulated investment companies for nonresident aliens is subject to specific requirements under section 246(c). Treatment of dividends from regulated investment companies is amended under section 854 of the Code, with specific provisions related to the maximum rate of tax on dividends. If a regulated investment company receives less than 95 percent of its gross income as dividends during a taxable year, it may be subject to a different tax rate under section 1(h). The maximum tax rate on dividends for regulated investment companies is determined based on the percentage of gross income received as dividends. If the company receives less than 95 percent of its gross income as dividends, rules similar to those for net short-term and long-term capital gains apply in computing the maximum tax rate. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002, including changes to the maximum tax rate on dividends for regulated investment companies and the exclusion of dividends from investment income.
